message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis of Von Gierke’s disease, which is caused by deficient glucose-6-phosphatase. Debranching enzyme is deficient in Type III glycogen storage disease, Lysosomal α-1,4-glucosidase is deficient in Pompe disease, and Muscle glycogen phosphorylase is deficient in McArdle disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest that the patient has glycogen storage disease type I. Among the options, Glucose-6-phosphatase is the deficient enzyme in this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings indicate that the patient has a metabolic disorder, most likely a glycogen storage disease. Among the options, Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is associated with hepatomegaly, elevated lactate and uric acid, and elevated triglyceride levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a possible diagnosis of glycogen storage disease. Among the options, only glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is a cause of glycogen storage disease, and it leads to elevated lactate and triglyceride levels. Hepatomegaly is also a common feature of glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a disorder in glucose metabolism, possibly glycogen storage disease. Among the options, glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is associated with hepatomegaly, increased lactate, and hypertriglyceridemia. The other enzymes listed are associated with different types of glycogen storage diseases with different symptoms and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presenting symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a metabolic disorder. Among the options, Glucose-6-phosphatase is responsible for releasing glucose from glycogen, and its deficiency leads to glycogen storage disease type I which presents with symptoms like hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and lactic acidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a metabolic disorder. Among the options, Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (also known as Von Gierke's disease) can cause hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, and hypertriglyceridemia. The other enzymes listed do not have these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including weakness and dizziness early in the morning, suggest a metabolic disorder. The elevated triglyceride levels and the presence of hepatomegaly suggest glycogen storage disease. Among the options, Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is the most likely cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of weakness, dizziness, sweating, and vertigo suggest hypoglycemia, and the laboratory findings of elevated lactate and triglycerides suggest a disorder of fatty acid metabolism. Among the options, glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, also known as Von Gierke's disease, is consistent with these findings due to its involvement in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of glycogen storage disease, and among the options, Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is associated with elevated lactate, uric acid and triglyceride levels. Debranching enzyme deficiency is associated with hepatomegaly, but not the specific laboratory findings mentioned. Lysosomal α-1,4-glucosidase deficiency is associated with Pompe disease, which presents with muscle weakness but not the other symptoms mentioned. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency is associated with exercise intolerance, but not the other symptoms mentioned.
